title: AB 2770
content: The State of California enacts the following. Section 22972 of the Business and Professions Code in California requires retailers to have and maintain a license to sell cigarettes or tobacco products at each retail location starting June 30, 2004. The license must be displayed prominently to the public and is not transferable. Retailers who cease business or have their license suspended must surrender it to the board. Retailers in California must renew their license annually, with a 12-month validity period. Applications must be filed by April 15, 2004, including applicant details and addresses of retail locations. Multiple locations require a designated address for correspondence. Applicants for a license in California must affirm they have not committed felonies or violated any regulations. They must also provide the license or permit numbers for any other licenses they hold. Applicants for a license in California must affirm the completeness and truthfulness of their application, with penalties for providing false information. The board may investigate the information provided and may issue a license without further investigation if the applicant holds a valid license from the Department of Alcoholic Beverage Control for the same location. The board also provides electronic means for applicants to download and submit applications. The board in California offers electronic means for applicants to download and submit applications for a retail license. Each application requires a fee of $265 per retail location, with separate licenses needed for multiple locations. Renewal applications must also be submitted with the same fee per location starting from January 1, 2017. Section 22973.3 of the Business and Professions Code is amended to require specific information on the application for a tobacco product license, including applicant details and retail location information. Multiple retail locations under one applicant must provide a central address for correspondence. The applicant must affirm they have not been convicted of a felony or violated any laws related to tobacco products. If there are other licenses or permits, the applicant must provide the license or permit numbers. The applicant must affirm the completeness and truthfulness of the application, with a warning of penalties for providing false information. The board may investigate the information provided and may issue a license without further investigation if the applicant holds a valid license from the Department of Alcoholic Beverage Control for the same location. The board shall provide electronic means for applicants to download and submit applications. The board requires applicants to submit applications electronically and pay a fee of $265 per retail location. Renewal applications also require a fee of $265 per location. The board will report to the Legislature by January 1, 2019, on the funding adequacy for the Cigarette and Tobacco Products Licensing Act of 2003. The report will include data and recommendations on the annual licensing fee levels for effective enforcement. This section applies to retailers selling untaxed tobacco products without a valid license. Retailers with a valid license to sell cigarettes can also sell untaxed tobacco products under the same license. Section 22977.1 of the Business and Professions Code is amended to require distributors and wholesalers to file an application by April 15, 2004, accompanied by a $1,000 fee for each location to obtain a license. Every distributor and wholesaler starting business after May 2004 must file an application with the board at least 30 days before starting sales. The application must be accompanied by a $1,200 fee for each location, and the board will issue a license within 30 days of receiving the application and fee. For calendar years starting in 2005 to 2017, distributors and wholesalers must renew their license with a $1,000 fee per location. From 2017 onwards, the fee is $1,200 per location. Section 22990.5 of the Business and Professions Code prohibits the appropriation of tax revenues from cigarettes and tobacco products for enforcing the California Cigarette and Tobacco Products Licensing Act of 2003 starting July 1, 2019. Section 22990.7 is also added to the Business and Professions Code. The board is required to report annually to the Legislature, Governor, and Department of Finance on the funding adequacy for the Cigarette and Tobacco Products Licensing Act of 2003, including recommendations on licensing fee levels for effective enforcement. The report must comply with Section 9795 of the Government Code.
